submission.furtherContent: Learn more about how we use this data (this link opens in a new tab)

introduction.description:
• You have been selected to complete the Annual Business Survey (ABS).
  • This survey is a key resource for understanding the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.
  • The information you supply helps to measure the UK economy and is used by the government to determine economic policy. The ABS also influences decisions on company and personal taxation and on interest rates.
  • You cannot appeal your selection. Your business was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
  • You still need to complete this survey even if it does not seem relevant. All returns are important as it helps us produce better statistics.
  • We will treat your data securely and confidentially.
  • View the latest publication produced from this survey (this link opens in a new tab)
introduction.secondaryDescription:
View the questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)

This questionnaire is divided into sections, which ask for information about:
introduction.title: You are completing this for ru_name (trad_as)

collapsibles.title: Reporting period
collapsibles.description:
This section asks about the period for which your business will be reporting.

Your return period should cover the calendar year 2022. If no figures are available for that period, your return should relate to a business year that ends between 6 April 2022 and 5 April 2023.

collapsibles.title: Income
collapsibles.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's income. This includes questions about total turnover and environmental turnover.

This section asks for information regarding your business's expenditure.

This includes:

  • employment costs
  • costs of goods and energy products bought for resale
  • costs of all other materials, goods and services
  • rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government
  • HM Revenue and Customs Drawback
collapsibles.title: Expenditure

collapsibles.description: This section asks for information regarding the value of stocks held by your business.
collapsibles.title: Value of stocks held
Capital assets
collapsibles.description: This section asks you to provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.

collapsibles.title: International trade in services
collapsibles.description: This section asks for information regarding your businesses international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.

collapsibles.title: International trade in goods
collapsibles.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of goods.

collapsibles.title: Research and Development
collapsibles.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's research and development.

introduction.tertiaryDescription:
• The statistics produced help to improve the overall quality of National Accounts and the measurement of Gross Domestic Product (this link opens in a new tab)
  • In addition to the National Accounts, the ABS is also used by the Scottish Government and Welsh Government in the compilation of both regional country specific Input and Output tables and Indices of Production.
  • It also provides a major contribution to the Blue Book, which is produced annually by our National Accounts Team and used to inform HM Treasury in managing economic policy.

pages.title: Are you able to report for the calendar year [Start Date] to [End Date]?
pages.description: Your return should relate to the calendar year 2022.
pages.guidance:
Traded for part of the year?

Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'

Cannot report for this calendar year?

Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'

options.label: Yes, I can report for this period
No, I need to report for a different period

pages.title: What dates will you be reporting for?
pages.description: If figures are not available for the calendar year 2022, your return should relate to a business year that ends between 6 April 2022 and 5 April 2023.
pages.guidance:
Did your business only trade for part of the year?

Please provide figures for the period in which you were trading.

Has your business commenced trading during 2022?

Your return should cover the period from the commencement of your business until 31 December 2022 or, alternatively, any date up to 5 April 2023.

Has your business ceased trading during 2022?

Your return should cover the period 1 January 2022 to the date you ceased to trade or, alternatively, from the beginning of your last business year up to the cessation date.

sections.introductionContent:
The ABS collects information to better understand the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.

Please read the following information before starting the survey.

  • Questions in this survey ask for figures either for GB or the UK. Instructions will be provided for each question to know which figures to provide.
  • Questions that ask for UK data should relate to business activity in England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, but exclude the Channel Islands and Isle of Man. For GB data, exclude Northern Ireland.
  • You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
  • Please round your figures to the nearest £1,000.
  • You can save a copy of your answers at the end of this questionnaire using the ‘Download as PDF’ button.
  • Refer to additional guidance accompanying each question for more information.

View the questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)

What activity to include in this survey

Any activity outside the UK lasting for more than one year should be excluded from this questionnaire, except all installation activities outside the UK, which should be included regardless of the length of period of the work carried out.

Any work done in connection with overseas contracts where employees travel abroad regularly for short periods should be included and any overseas activity which is deemed to be capital expenditure in that country should be excluded.

Reporting period

You will be asked to report for [Start Date] to [End Date]. If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.
sections.title: How to complete and reporting period

sections.introductionContent:
This section asks for information regarding your business's income. This includes questions about total turnover and environmental turnover.

This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.
sections.title: Income

confirmation.title: You have reported your business's total turnover for the period [From] to [To] to be [Total turnover]. Is this correct?

negative.label: No, I need to change this

pages.definitionContent: This refers to the total amount receivable in respect of invoices raised during the period of the return, for the sale of goods and services. Figures should be given gross of indirect taxes, duties, and levies (except VAT) invoiced to the customer.
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • progress payments on work in progress on long-term contracts
  • total turnover and/or commission or fees received if you do not trade on your own account
  • Customs and Excise duty payable
  • intercompany charges

Exclude:

  • VAT
pages.title: For the period [From] to [To], what was [Ru Name]'s total turnover?
pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • all sales of goods, except fixed capital assets, including exports and goods purchased and resold without processing. Please note that a product that is cut, washed, packaged, or bottled is classed as unprocessed
  • provision of goods and/or services to other parts of your company or organisation which are not covered by this return. These should be valued as if sold to an independent customer. If you are unable to supply figures on this basis, please value them at transfer cost
  • work done on customers’ materials, including the value of any additional materials added
  • income from construction activity, even if subcontracted
  • income from all industrial and non-industrial services rendered
  • income derived from the renting of property
  • amounts received for the right to use patents, trademarks and copyrights
  • receipts from government for goods and services supplied free, or at a subsidised rate, under the National Health Service and similar public services
  • transport, insurance, and packaging charges, less amounts for returnable containers, invoiced by your business even if invoiced separately
  • income from subcontracted activities
  • for commission work, where you do not hold title to goods sold, the commission or fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included here are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
  • the value of second-hand goods taken in part exchange, such second-hand goods should also be recorded as purchases
  • service charges for credit provided, but not interest charges
  • the value of vouchers, tokens, and coupons used by customers as a means of payment, but not the sale of such vouchers to customers
  • royalty payments received
  • agricultural merchants, sales to farmers

Exclude:

  • output for own final use
  • income recorded as extraordinary income in your accounts
  • the sale of vehicles previously treated as capital assets during the period
  • interest payments received and other similar income
  • amounts received from the sale of fixed capital assets
  • amounts received from the sale of patents, trademarks and copyrights
  • grants from any source
  • subsidies from UK public authorities and the European Union (EU)
  • value of insurance claims received
  • income derived from the renting of land if recorded separately within your accounts
  • income recorded as 'Other Operating Income' in your accounts
  • all trade, cash, or other discounts and rebates. Record turnover net of these
  • sales by other businesses operating on your premises as well as commission received in such sales
  • dividends received
  • amounts arising from donations and fundraising activities
  • the full value of any transfer fees received
pages.description: Report GB figures. An informed estimate is acceptable. Refer to the 'additional guidance' for more information.

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.
answers.label: Total turnover

pages.guidance:
Include:

  • progress payments on work in progress
  • total turnover and/or commission or fees received if you do not trade on your own account
  • Customs and Excise duty payable

Exclude:

  • VAT
pages.description: Report GB figures. An informed estimate is acceptable.
pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • all sales of goods (except fixed capital assets) including exports and goods purchased and resold without processing, please note that a product that is cut, washed, packaged, bottled etc is classed as unprocessed so should be included in 2.1 (a)
  • provision of goods and/or services to other parts of your company or organisation which are not covered by this return. These should be valued as if sold to an independent customer. If you are unable to supply figures on this basis, please value them at transfer cost
  • work done on customers’ materials (including the value of any additional materials added)
  • income from construction activity (even if subcontracted);
  • income from all industrial and non-industrial services rendered
  • income derived from the renting of property;
  • amounts received for the right to use patents, trademarks, copyrights etc
  • receipts from government for goods and services supplied free (or at a subsidised rate) under the National Health Service and similar public services
  • transport, insurance and packaging charges (less amounts for returnable containers) invoiced by your business (even if invoiced separately)
  • income from subcontracted activities
  • for commission work (ie where you do not hold title to goods sold), the commission/fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included here are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
  • the value of second-hand goods taken in part exchange (such second-hand goods should also be recorded as purchases)
  • service charges for credit provided (but not interest charges)
  • the value of vouchers, tokens and coupons used by customers as a means of payment (but not the sale of such vouchers etc to customers)
  • royalty payments received
  • agricultural merchants - sales to farmers

Exclude:

  • output for own final use
  • income recorded as extraordinary income in your accounts
  • the sale of vehicles previously treated as capital assets during the period. Include these in section E
  • interest payments received and other similar income
  • amounts received from the sale of fixed capital assets
  • amounts received from the sale of patents, trademarks, copyrights etc
  • grants from any source
  • subsidies from UK public authorities and the European Union (EU)
  • value of insurance claims received
  • income derived from the renting of land (if recorded separately within your accounts)
  • income recorded as “Other Operating Income” in your accounts
  • all trade, cash or other discounts and rebates (ie record turnover net of these)
  • sales by other businesses operating on your premises (as well as commission received in such sales)
  • dividends received
  • amounts arising from donations and fundraising activities
  • the full value of any transfer fees received
pages.title: Of [Total turnover], what is your business's turnover arising from the sale of goods purchased and resold without further processing?

answers.label: Turnover arising from the sale of goods purchased and resold without further processing
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • all sales of goods (except fixed capital assets) including exports and goods purchased and resold without processing, please note that a product that is cut, washed, packaged, bottled etc is classed as unprocessed so should be included in 2.1 (a)
  • provision of goods and/or services to other parts of your company or organisation which are not covered by this return. These should be valued as if sold to an independent customer. If you are unable to supply figures on this basis, please value them at transfer cost
  • work done on customers’ materials (including the value of any additional materials added)
  • income from construction activity (even if subcontracted);
  • income from all industrial and non-industrial services rendered
  • income derived from the renting of property;
  • amounts received for the right to use patents, trademarks, copyrights etc
  • receipts from government for goods and services supplied free (or at a subsidised rate) under the National Health Service and similar public services
  • transport, insurance and packaging charges (less amounts for returnable containers) invoiced by your business (even if invoiced separately)
  • income from subcontracted activities
  • for commission work (ie where you do not hold title to goods sold), the commission/fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included here are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
  • the value of second-hand goods taken in part exchange (such second-hand goods should also be recorded as purchases)
  • service charges for credit provided (but not interest charges)
  • the value of vouchers, tokens and coupons used by customers as a means of payment (but not the sale of such vouchers etc to customers)
  • royalty payments received
  • agricultural merchants - sales to farmers

Exclude:

  • output for own final use
  • income recorded as extraordinary income in your accounts
  • the sale of vehicles previously treated as capital assets during the period. Include these in section E
  • interest payments received and other similar income
  • amounts received from the sale of fixed capital assets
  • amounts received from the sale of patents, trademarks, copyrights etc
  • grants from any source
  • subsidies from UK public authorities and the European Union (EU)
  • value of insurance claims received
  • income derived from the renting of land (if recorded separately within your accounts)
  • income recorded as “Other Operating Income” in your accounts
  • all trade, cash or other discounts and rebates (ie record turnover net of these)
  • sales by other businesses operating on your premises (as well as commission received in such sales)
  • dividends received
  • amounts arising from donations and fundraising activities
  • the full value of any transfer fees received
pages.title: Of [Total turnover], what is your business's turnover arising from all other sales of goods and services during the reporting period?
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • progress payments on work in progress
  • total turnover and/or commission or fees received if you do not trade on your own account
  • Customs and Excise duty payable
  • all fees and commissions received

Exclude:

  • VAT

answers.label: Turnover arising from all other sales of goods and services
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

pages.description: Report GB figures. An informed estimate is acceptable.

pages.guidance:
Include:

Goods and/or services that protect the environment that are produced by your business. For example:

  • production or installation of solar panels
  • waste collection, treatment and disposal services
  • environmental consultancy and training services

Exclude:

Goods and/or services that protect the environment that are used by your business. For example:

  • the use of energy saving light bulbs
  • the consumption of recycled materials
pages.title: Does your business produce goods or services that protect the environment?
Of [Total turnover], approximately what percentage related to the production of environmental goods or services?
pages.description: An informed estimate is acceptable.

pages.guidance:
Include:

  • accrued holiday pay
  • all overtime payments, bonuses, commissions
  • the cost to the employer of all expenses and benefits in-kind. These include assets transferred to employees such as cars, property, goods or other assets. Payments made on behalf of employees such as mileage allowances and fuel payments, unless the payments are in respect of travelling expenses. Subsidies to staff canteens, sports club membership, nurseries, playschemes and health insurance
  • employment costs paid to workers employed by the UK company and workers employed who are based overseas. These costs should only reflect the installation services activity carried out outside the UK
  • payments into pension funds providing retirement or death benefits for employees, including former employees or their dependents
  • any 'signing on' fees paid to employees

Exclude:

  • payments to working proprietors, partners and executive directors not in receipt of a regular salary, fees, or commission
  • travelling and subsistence expenses
  • payments to homeworkers on piecework rates
  • payments to employment agencies for the services of agency staff
  • rebates received from National Insurance Redundancy Fund
  • contributions by employers for their own personal pension schemes
  • employees' National Insurance contributions
pages.title: For the period [From] to [To], what was [Ru Name]'s expenditure on employment costs?

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.
answers.label: Total expenditure on employment costs

pages.description:
Report GB figures.

Wages and salaries are defined as the total compensation in cash or in-kind payable to all employees. State the amount paid before deductions but less any amounts for which you are reimbursed from government sources.
pages.definitionContent:
An employee is anyone aged 16 or over that your organisation pays directly from its payroll(s), in return for carrying out a full-time or part-time job or being on a training scheme.

Include:

  • all workers such as permanent, temporary, casual and seasonal workers, paid directly from this business's payroll(s)
  • those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example on parental leave, on holiday or on sick

Exclude:

  • former employees only receiving a pension
  • self-employed workers
  • subcontractors

pages.description:
Report GB figures.

State the net full delivered cost of purchases made during the period of this return whether or not they were used or resold during that period.

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.
answers.label: Total expenditure on goods bought for resale

pages.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on goods bought for resale?
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • any energy products bought for resale without further processing. For example, petroleum products including diesel, gas including LPG and hydrogen, and solid fuels including coal, coke, and charcoal
  • any goods bought for resale without further processing. For example, merchanted goods, goods purchased and resold without modification
  • non-deductible VAT
  • import and excise duties, less drawback

Exclude:

  • employment costs
  • all interest payments
  • amounts charged to capital account
  • capitalised building repairs
  • deductible VAT
pages.definitionLabel: Examples of goods bought for resale
pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • any goods bought on a ‘sale or return’ basis which were subsequently sold but exclude the cost of those returned unsold
  • the purchase price paid for the goods for resale excluding any duties paid by the seller
  • the full purchase price of property bought and sold in the same financial period, without development

Exclude:

  • the cost of materials purchased for use in the installation, repair, or maintenance of customers’ goods
  • food and drink requiring preparation before sale
  • any other goods 'sold' which are part of a service
  • the full value of any transfer fees paid out
  • excise duties paid by yourselves

answers.label: Total expenditure for all other costs of materials, goods and services
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

pages.definitionContent:
• post and telecommunication costs
  • advertising charges
  • commercial insurance premiums paid
pages.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on all other materials, goods, and services?
pages.description: Report GB figures.
pages.definitionLabel: Examples of other costs of materials, goods and services
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • all fees and commissions received
  • management fees
  • inter group charges

Exclude:

  • national non-domestic business rates
pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • all fuel costs purchased for use in the running of your business. For example, electricity, gas, oil, coal, coke, petrol and diesel
  • purchases of water used in the running of your business, including water extraction charges
  • sewerage charges and other costs of effluent and waste disposal
  • other goods and materials such as machine spares, packaging materials, and office materials charged to you. For example stationery and consumables
  • the costs of goods and materials purchased for use in the installation, repair, or maintenance of customers' goods
  • payments for hiring, leasing or renting plant, machinery and vehicles if acquired under operational leases, but not if purchased under hire purchase or finance leasing arrangements
  • amounts payable to other organisations for transport
  • road transport services purchased for own staff to use, for example, buses and taxis
  • purchases of computer and related services including consultancy charges on computer software and hardware and the cost of repair, maintenance, and installation of office and computing machinery
  • payments to employment agencies for the services of agency staff
  • labour recruitment administration costs
  • amounts, except those charged to the capital account, payable to others for the services of accountants, auditors, agents, solicitors and surveyors
  • amounts payable to other organisations and self-employed persons. For example, for labour they have supplied
  • amounts payable for the right to use patents, trademarks, copyrights, manufacturing rights and technical know-how
  • amounts payable to other organisations for technical research and studies
  • amounts payable for sea, air, and rail freight on goods transported
  • building repairs, maintenance, and contract cleaning services
  • payments to other businesses within the same group, for example, service companies
  • bank charges, excluding interest payments
  • rent paid on buildings or dwellings
  • amounts paid for licensing, inspection, and monitoring
  • staff travel
  • travelling and subsistence expenses for individual claims
  • congestion charges including related fines and penalties
  • royalty payments
  • the cost of any materials you have supplied for work done by you as a subcontractor
  • the cost of materials purchased for use in the installation, repair or maintenance of customers' goods
  • rental of telephone handsets and modems
  • purchase of telephone handsets and modems
  • payments to subcontractors
  • payments to homeworkers on piecework rates
  • payments for film and programme rights
  • exam costs and amounts payable for training packages
  • payments made to claimants
  • insurance costs which are passed on to the customer
  • any other goods or services purchased
  • management fees and/or inter group charges

Exclude:

  • all bank and other interest payments
  • bad debts including future provisions
  • any allowances for depreciation, amortisation, or obsolescence including future provisions
  • employment costs
  • hire purchase repayments
  • finance leasing payments
  • the cost of any items charged to the capital account including building repairs
  • fines and penalties except those related to congestion charges
  • amounts charged to capital account including computer hardware, software, and programs written by a third party to be used for more than one year
  • mortgage interest and mortgage loan payments
  • rent payments on land

answers.label: Total purchases of energy, goods, materials and services

pages.title: We have calculated your business's total purchases of energy, goods, materials and services, during the reporting period, to be [total]. Is this correct?
pages.totalTitle: Total purchases of energy, goods, materials and services

pages.description:
Report GB figures.

You should only include the value for the rates, duties, levies, and taxes listed below if your business paid these directly to government, statutory bodies or regulators. Do not include these taxes if they were paid as part of your purchase of goods, materials, and services.
pages.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on rates, duties, levies, and taxes paid to the government?

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.
answers.label: Expenditure on rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government

pages.guidance:
Include:

  • national non-domestic business rates
  • vehicle excise duty, also known as road, car, or vehicle tax
  • the Climate Change Levy (CCL), introduced in April 2001, is charged on industrial and commercial use of various forms of energy. For example, primary and secondary fuel for lighting, heating, motive power, and power for appliances

Exclude:

  • VAT
  • tax already included in the purchase of goods, materials, and services
  • Corporation Tax
  • Income Tax
  • Capital Gains Tax
  • any agreed reductions on the Climate Change Levy
pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • excise duties when paid directly to government by your business. For example, on alcohol, tobacco and hydrocarbon oil duty
  • any business rates or formula rates paid to local authorities or Department of Communities and Local Government (DCLG). Formula rates paid to DCLG applies to Great Britain only
  • stamp duties
  • import duties
  • export levies, for example, under the EU’s Common Agricultural Policy
  • regulator fees and any statutory amounts paid to: Environment Agency (EA), Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (OFGEM), Office of Water Service Regulation (OFWAT) in England and Wales and the Scottish Water and Sewerage Customers Council (SWSCC) in Scotland, Office of Communications (OFCOM) and Office of Rail and Road (ORR)
  • Consumer and Credit Act fees
  • franchise payments to government, for example, rail franchise premia
  • EU Emissions Trading System
  • CRC Energy Efficiency Scheme, formerly known as Carbon Reduction Commitment
  • sugar levy
  • Renewable Energy Obligations
  • levies paid to government levy-funded bodies, for example, Financial Services Compensation Scheme, Agriculture & Horticulture Development Board and Sea Fish Industry Authority
  • Vehicle Registration Tax paid upon registering a new or imported vehicle for the first time

Exclude:

  • water rates and sewerage charges
  • council tax, payable via local authorities in respect of your rented property
  • operators’ licences
  • net payments to trade associations and similar bodies
  • Inheritance Tax
  • Air Passenger Duty
  • Landfill Tax
  • Insurance Premium Tax
  • Lottery Duty
  • fees and other licences, for example, passports, television, boating and fishing
  • rent payments on land

pages.guidance:
Include:

  • the amount of duty payable during the year on goods of your own manufacture, which were sold duty paid
  • if you are in the tobacco industry, include the amount of End Product Tax or import duty payable
  • tobacco, cigarettes, and cigars
  • alcoholic drinks
  • petroleum and petroleum products
  • import duties

Exclude:

  • VAT
  • deposits
  • Vehicle Excise Duty, also known as ‘motor vehicle duty’ or ‘road fund tax’
pages.description: Report GB figures. These are amounts payable directly to HM Revenue and Customs.

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.
answers.label: Expenditure on HM Revenues and Customs duty payable

pages.title: Of [Expenditure on rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government], what was your business's expenditure on HM Revenue and Customs duty?
For the reporting period, what was your business's total amount of excise drawback and allowances receivable from HM Revenue and Customs?
pages.description: Report GB figures.

answers.label: Total amount of excise drawback and allowances receivable from HM Revenue and Customs
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

sections.introductionContent:
This section asks for information regarding your business's expenditure.

This includes:

  • employment costs
  • costs of goods bought for resale
  • costs of all other materials, goods, and services
  • rates, duties, levies, and taxes paid to the government
  • HM Revenue and Customs Drawback

This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.
sections.title: Expenditure

sections.introductionContent:
This section asks for information regarding the value of stocks held by your business.

  • Inventories should be valued on the basis used in your financial statements i.e. on the basis of UK GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) or International GAAP.
  • Where long-term contract balances are included in stocks, they should be recorded net of progress payments.
  • Where the outcome of the contract is known with reasonable certainty and a proportion of the contract income has been recognised as turnover, progress payments should be disregarded.
  • Value of stocks held includes Work in Progress but excludes VAT, consignment stock, stock you do not hold title to and progress payments on long-term contracts.

This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

Work in Progress consists of goods and services that have been partially processed, fabricated, or assembled by the producer but that are not usually sold or turned over to others without further processing. These products include Work in Progress belonging to the unit, even if the products in question are in the possession of third parties.

Equally, products held by the unit which belong to third parties are excluded, as are partially completed structures for which the ultimate owner is deemed to have taken ownership, either by the existence of a contract of sale or purchase, or because the production is for own use.
sections.title: Value of stocks held

pages.title: What was [Ru Name]'s total value of all stocks held at [From] and [To]?
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • work in progress

Exclude:

  • VAT
  • consignment stock
  • stock you hold but do not own title to
  • progress payments on long-term contracts
pages.description:
Report UK figures.

The figures for the beginning and end of the period should be on the same basis in terms of valuation and business units covered.
pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • all stocks that you own title to, of goods and materials on hand for sale or processing, other than goods supplied to another party with a reservation of title clause if treated as turnover
  • all stocks owned and held by you in the UK or currently in transit within the UK
  • all stocks owned and held by you overseas or currently in transit abroad
  • the value of any goods let out on hire, only if they were charged to current account when acquired and do not rank as capital items for taxation purposes
  • products that you own title to in intermediate stages of completion
  • duty on stocks held out of bond
  • long term business contract balances with progress payments treated in line with UK GAAP or International GAAP
  • contracts not yet finalised such as commission fees for work carried out
  • building work carried out by yourselves, including finished properties built by yourselves with the intention to sell

Exclude:

  • duty of stocks held in bond
  • products in intermediate stages of completion that do not belong to you

answers.label: Total value of all stocks at the beginning of the period
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

answers.label: Total value of all stocks at the end of the period
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

pages.description:
Report UK figures.

Report the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.

Information requested may not always be found on a register of capital assets, and should include all assets of any value, even if this is below your Asset Register threshold.
pages.definitionContent:
Include:

  • land and land improvements or preparation, for own use
  • other natural resources and non-produced assets, for example, subsoil assets, crude oil, coal and water abstraction
  • non-produced assets, for example, goodwill, patents, licences, concessions, contracts, trade dress, mastheads, domain names, collective and certification marks
  • existing buildings and structures for own use or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
  • major refurbishment, newly built and construction work for own use
  • construction of structures such as oil wells, platforms, mines, pipes, power lines, transport infrastructure, wind farms, turbines, and steel frameworks
  • transport assets and equipment, for example, new and used vehicles, special purpose vehicles, trailers, ships, boats, aircraft and railway rolling stock, motorcycles, bicycles, parts, accessories, and major repairs
  • computers and hardware devices, for example, printers, servers, monitors, keyboards, and terminals
  • computer software programs and databases
  • telecommunication equipment, for example, phones, fax machines, switchboards, transmitters, CCTV equipment, TV cameras, burglar or fire alarms
  • electrical equipment and electronic appliances
  • furniture and office equipment
  • small tools
  • general and special purpose equipment
  • fabricated products, for example, textile, leather, plastic, and metal products
  • intellectual property assets, for example, recordings, films and performances, manuscripts and publications, plans, instructions, and designs
  • the purchase costs and disposal proceeds of fixed assets, together with any other amounts treated as capital items for taxation purposes
  • the total capital value of assets that have been bought on hire purchase in the period covered by this survey
  • assets acquired under finance lease where you are responsible for repairs and maintenance
  • assets owned by the business but leased to another business under an operating lease where you are responsible for repairs and maintenance

Exclude:

  • assets acquired in taking over an existing business or sold as part of a going concern
  • assets of a capital nature acquired for resale rather than for use within business, for example, stocks of vehicles held by motor traders
  • assets like TV adverts or copyrights
  • assets leased to another business under finance lease, such as repair and maintenance are carried out by the other business, known as a lessee
  • assets acquired under an operating lease, such as responsibility for repair and maintenance is borne by the owner, or lessor, of the asset
  • asset transfers between companies owned by the same enterprise, except where the asset value is considered to be a 'new' acquisition or disposal within the company accounts
  • software licences of up to one year
  • structures that are used primarily as residences or dwellings
  • utilities such as gas, electricity, and water
  • research and development
  • works of art, for example, paintings and sculptures, even if acquired or disposed of by dealers, galleries, or museums
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • assets within the UK
  • non-deductible VAT
  • delivery, installation and decommissioning costs
  • transfer costs, professional charges, contracts and fees, for example, surveyors' fees, stamp duty, taxes and legal costs. Include costs invoiced to you separately
  • expenditure on replacing assets destroyed in circumstances, for example fire, which have given rise to a successful insurance claim
  • expenditure on assets acquired for hiring, renting and other leasing purposes, but not finance leasing
  • capital expenditure at any site belonging to the business where operations have not yet begun
  • grants and allowances from government sources, statutory bodies or local authorities that have been used to acquire or create assets used in production
  • finance relating to Public Private Partnership or Private Finance Initiative that has been used to acquire assets
  • progress payments or deposits covering long-term contracts acquiring fixed assets
  • all work of a capital nature carried out by your own staff, including labour costs and the cost of purchases consumed in the work
  • professional charges and installation costs associated with capital assets must be reported with the asset value

Exclude:

  • assets outside the UK
  • deductible VAT
  • current repair and maintenance costs
  • costs of ongoing management of computer software and databases
  • revaluations of assets, for example, depreciation, amortisation, and impairment charges
  • interest and instalment payments under finance leasing arrangements
  • capital expenditure on assets for use outside the UK, except ships and aircraft
  • the proceeds from an insurance claim against the loss of fixed assets
pages.additionalInfoContent:
Include:

  • land and land improvements or preparation, for own use
  • other natural resources and non-produced assets, eg subsoil assets, crude oil, coal, water abstraction, etc
  • non-produced assets eg goodwill, patents, licences, concessions, contracts, trade dress, mastheads, domain names, collective and certification marks
  • existing buildings and structures for own use or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
  • major refurbishment, newly built and construction work for own use
  • construction of structures such as oil wells, platforms, mines, pipes, power lines, transport infrastructure, wind farms, turbines and steel frameworks
  • delivery, installation and decommissioning costs
  • transport assets and equipment eg new and used vehicles, special purpose vehicles, trailers, ships, boats, aircraft and railway rolling stock, motorcycles, bicycles, invalid carriages, parts, accessories and major repairs
  • computers and hardware devices eg printers, servers, monitors, keyboards and terminals
  • computer software programs and databases
  • telecommunication equipment eg phones, fax machines, switchboards, transmitters, CCTV equipment, TV cameras, burglar or fire alarms
  • electrical equipment and electronic appliances
  • furniture and office equipment
  • small tools
  • general and special purpose equipment
  • fabricated products eg textile, leather, plastic and metal products
  • intellectual property assets eg recordings, films and performances, manuscripts and publications, plans, instructions and designs
  • transfer costs, professional charges, contracts and fees eg surveyors' fees, stamp duty, taxes and legal costs

Exclude:

  • current repair and maintenance costs
  • structures that are used primarily as residences (dwellings)
  • utilities such as gas, electricity and water
  • research and development
  • costs of ongoing management of computer software and databases
  • works of art eg paintings and sculptures, even if acquired or disposed of by dealers, galleries or museums
  • revaluations of assets (eg depreciation, amortisation and impairment charges)

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.
answers.label: Total value of capital assets from acquisitions

pages.title: For the period [From] to [To], what was [Ru Name]'s total value of capital assets acquired and disposed of?

sections.title: Capital assets
sections.introductionContent:
This section asks you to provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.

This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

Information requested may not always be found on a register of capital assets, and should include all assets of any value, even if this is below your Asset Register threshold.

pages.description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident, hence transactions in services with these entities should be regarded as international trade in services.

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.
answers.label: Total income from services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK

pages.definitionLabel: Examples of services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations
pages.definitionContent:
• repair of construction equipment and computers, but not maintenance or any other repairs
  • the hiring out of plant, machinery and other goods such as operational leasing
  • advertising and commission as an agent, excluding the value of imports or exports of goods
pages.title: For the period [From] to [To], what was [Ru Name]'s income from services provided to individuals, enterprises, or other organisations based outside the UK?
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
  • transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK
  • merchanting profits and losses on goods bought and sold abroad without entering the UK
  • management fees

Exclude:

  • dividend or interest payments
  • transactions in financial assets or liabilities
  • transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK
  • salaries of staff seconded abroad if their absence is for more than one year
  • business travel services such as accommodation and meals whilst abroad
  • trade in goods

pages.definitionLabel: Examples of services provided by individuals, enterprises or other organisations
pages.description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident, hence transactions in services with these entities should be regarded as international trade in services.
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
  • transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK
  • merchanting profits and losses on goods bought and sold abroad without entering the UK
  • management fees

Exclude:

  • dividend or interest payments
  • transactions in financial assets or liabilities
  • transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK
  • salaries of staff seconded abroad if their absence is for more than one year
  • business travel services such as accommodation and meals whilst abroad
  • trade in goods
pages.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on services provided by individuals, enterprises, or other organisations based outside the UK?

• repair of construction equipment and computers, but not maintenance or any other repairs

sections.introductionContent:
This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.

This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.
sections.title: International trade in services

sections.introductionContent:
This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of goods.

This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.
sections.title: International trade in goods

pages.definitionContent:
Goods are specific, tangible commodities.

  • raw materials
  • semi or finished manufactured goods
  • food, beverages, and tobacco
  • basic materials
  • oil and other fuel
pages.title: For the period [From] to [To], did [Ru Name] export goods to individuals, enterprises, or other organisations based outside the UK?
pages.guidance:
Include:

  • transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
  • transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK

Exclude:

  • trade in services
  • transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK
pages.description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident, hence transactions in goods with these entities should be regarded as international trade in goods.

  • transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK

Exclude:

  • trade in services
  • transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK

  • raw materials
  • semi or finished manufactured goods
  • food, beverages, and tobacco
  • basic materials
  • oil and other fuel

The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

pages.title: For the reporting period, did your business import goods from individuals, enterprises, or other organisations based outside the UK?

sections.introductionContent:
This section asks for information regarding your business's research and development.

This section requires answers based on business activity within the UK.

Research and Development covers three types of activity:

  • basic research
  • applied research
  • experimental development

R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:

Novel: to be aimed at new findings

Creative: to be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses

Uncertain: to be uncertain about the final outcome

Systematic: to be planned and budgeted

Transferable or reproducible: to lead to results that could possibly be reproduced
sections.title: Research and Development

pages.definitionContent:
Research and Development covers three types of activity:

  • basic research
  • applied research
  • experimental development

R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:

Novel: to be aimed at new findings

Creative: to be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses

Uncertain: to be uncertain about the final outcome

Systematic: to be planned and budgeted

Transferable or reproducible: to lead to results that could possibly be reproduced
pages.title: Did [Ru Name] carry out any in-house Research and Development for the period [From] to [To], or intend to do so in the next reporting period?
pages.definitionLabel: What we mean by 'Research and Development'
pages.description: Base your answer on business activity within the UK.

pages.guidance:
Please include details of:

  • any zero figures

Any significant impacts upon your data resulting from changes to your business. For example:

  • changes to your business structure
  • type of activity undertaken

Changes in the accounting approaches you have taken. For example:

  • change of accounting standard such as IFRS
  • regulatory changes
pages.title: Please provide any further details that will help us understand your figures and tell an industry story
pages.description:
Explain any changes in your figures from your previous return, if applicable. If you provide comments, we are less likely to contact you with data queries.

Make sure you continue to the next page and select 'submit answers' at the bottom.
